section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials Drawing and writing supplies, Alphabet Cards, We Read, Fox Can Fix It!

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we read A House in the Sky. We saw the letter w in the word warbler and the letter x in the word box.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Teach Ww Alphabet Cards Show the Alphabet Cards for letters Ww. Say the letter aloud and have children repeat. This is uppercase W. The letter W makes the /w/ sound you hear in the word wagon. This is lowercase w. The letter w makes the /w/ you hear in wolf.
Teach Xx Alphabet Cards Show the Alphabet Cards for letters Xx. Say the letter aloud and have children repeat. This is lowercase x. The letter x makes the /ks/ sound you hear in x-ray.
Explain the Activity Share We Read and Fox Can Fix It !. Today we will read a book about the letters Ww and a book about the letters Xx.
Read Read aloud We Read with the following prompt.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Give a thumbs-up when you hear a word that begins with the /w/ sound.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Read Read aloud Fox Can Fix It! with the following prompt.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Touch your chin when you hear a word that has the /ks/ sound.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Model Model writing uppercase and lowercase letters Ww and Xx. Provide drawing and writing supplies. Guide children in practicing forming their letters.

As you read We Read, stop at each word that begins with the letter Ww. Have children say /w/ and the word that begins with Ww. As you read Fox Can Fix It!, stop at each word that has the /ks/ sound. Have children say /ks/ and the word that has the /ks/ sound.

For a challenge, after reading We Read, ask children to try to remember all the words that begin with the /w/ sound and the letter Ww. After reading Fox Can Fix It!, ask children to try to remember all the words have the /ks/ sound and the letter Xx.

Spanish-speaking children will likely know three sounds for the letter x: /ks/ as in “examen”; /h/ as in “Mexico”; and /ch/ as in “Xela,” a city in Guatemala. Remind children that we are studying the sound /ks/, which is the most common sound of the letter in the English language.

To help children with auditory discrimination challenges, exaggerate the movements of your mouth as you form each letter sound. Ask children to notice the way your lips form an o for the /w/ sound, while your lips form nearly a straight line and your teeth show a bit to form the /ks/ position. Invite children to move their mouths the same way as they make the letter sound. As they practice, have them listen for the sound.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials Magnetic Letters

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we read A House in the Sky. We talked about the problems different animals had and how they solved them. Who can remember the box turtle’s problem? What did the turtle do to solve this problem?
Just like the turtle solved his problem by hiding in his shell, when we have a problem, we look for a way to solve it.
Today we have an alphabet problem to solve. The letters are all mixed up! We need to put these letters in ABC order. Let’s see if we can solve our problem!

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Set Up Place the letters in front of you. Place the letter B next to the letter A. Place the letter C next to the letter B. Continue this process for the letters D, E, and F.
Ask Ask children which letter comes next. Place the letter G next to the letter F. Continue this process for letters H, I, J, and K.

Repeat Ask children which letter comes next. Place the letter L next to the letter K. Continue this process, allowing individual children to add new letters. Encourage children to help each other as they arrange the magnetic letters in alphabetical order. Continue this activity until all the magnetic letters are arranged in alphabetical order

Talk About Problem-Solving Techniques Once the letters are in alphabetical order, invite children to reflect on the activity. What was the problem we had with the letters? How did we solve our problem?

Scaffold this activity by only using letters A through M or stopping before all letters have been arranged. Walk children through the activity by saying the letter names aloud each round. Sing “The Alphabet Song” with children to help them remember the correct order of the letters.

Challenge children to name words that begin with each letter as it is placed, such as apple and ant for the letter a. Allow children to take turns arranging the letters in alphabetical order independently and let children work together as a group to foster communication skills.
Help multilingual learners identify the letters of the English alphabet. Take time, as needed, to review letter names and sing “The Alphabet Song” with children.

Encourage children to build their fine motor skills by picking up individual Magnetic Letters with their thumb and forefinger. See if they can gently place the letter in the appropriate place. Provide support as needed.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials Activity Cards

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we read A House in the Sky. We learned about different animals and the different homes they have. Who can name one animal home we learned about? What animals live in that home?
I will show you a picture of an animal home and tell you a little about it. Then, you will say what animals might live there and tell us why that animal home is a good place for that animal to live.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Ask Show one picture card and ask the question on the back of the card, offering extra challenge or support, as needed.
Extend Use the last question on the back of the card to go beyond the text and make connections to other animals.
Repeat Continue the activity using the next picture card.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Every animal has a home, whether it’s a cave, a hole in a tree, or a nest in a tree. No matter what the home is, animals use the home to feel safe and cozy, and to raise their family. How are animal homes like our homes?

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Before you play, explain that some animals live on land and some live in water. Birds, bats, and many insects spend most of their time in the air. Put the words land, water, and air in the middle of the table so children can point as a response during the activity.

Challenge children to sort the pictures of the animals by where they live. Encourage them to compare and contrast the animals who live in different places. Then ask them to brainstorm more animals that live in each place.

Explain that the animals in A House in the Sky are naturally found in different places. Some, like the badger, are found in many places around the world, while others, like the box turtle, are found in more limited ranges. Invite children to name some animals found in their country of origin. Find pictures of these animals on the internet and display them for children to see.

Sentence starters and sentence frames, such as those on the Activity Cards, offer support for language output for multilingual learners or children who struggle to respond in complete sentences. Encourage children to use them when when talking about animals that are native to their country of origin.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials Activity Cards

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we will read the poem, “At the Pond,” and learn about what makes the pond a great place for the animals that live there.

In this activity, we will talk about the different animals at the pond: what they do, what they eat, and what they see. I will show you a picture of an animal at the pond. Then we’ll talk about why the pond is a great home for that animal.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Ask Show one picture card and ask the question on the back of the card, offering extra challenge or support, as needed.
Extend Use the last question on the back of the card to deepen children’s understanding on how animals find food in the pond habitat.
Repeat Continue the activity using the next picture card.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: All of these animals live at the pond! Why is the pond a great place to live for these animals? Is there another place you can name that would make a good home for these animals? If you were an animal who lived at the pond, what animal would you be? Why would the pond be a good animal home for you?

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: While talking about each animal on the Activity Cards, point to the same animal shown in “At the Pond.” Say the name of the animal and have children repeat the animal name.

Challenge children to name other animals not mentioned in the poem. Invite children to explain why the additional animals shared would feel at home at the pond. Invite children to discuss how the new animals would find food, feel safe, and raise a family at the pond.

Find the translation for the word “pond” on the Internet. For example, the Spanish words for pond may be estanque, la charka, or la balsa. Have them use two or three words in English to describe an animal, as classmates try to guess which animal it is.
section-block.ac_mod_teacher-card_d_hed: Auditory Discrimination and Gross Motor Skills
section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Invite children to make the sounds of different animals that live at the pond: a croaking frog, a chirping bird, a butterfly flapping its wings, a rabbit nibbling grass, a grasshopper rubbing its legs together, and so on. If classmates have a hard time guessing the animal based on its sound, encourage the child to act out the animal’s movements.
